position.marginalia_text: Qui Hominum, Rerumq[ue] Artem habet, solus est maximarum Actionum Executor.

marginalia.translation: He who holds the skills of men and matter, is the sole performer of the greatest actions.

position.marginalia_text: In hominum, rerumq[ue] Sympathijs, et Antipathijs, peritè, diligenterq[ue] vtendis; Illa Miraculoru[m] Ars, quam mihi animus pollicetur. Ars Hominu[m], constat tribus fer[e] Artibus, Ethica, Politica, et Eloquentia: Ars rerum, tribus item Artibus, Physica, Mathematica, et Mechanica. Nihil valet, sine quotidiana praxi, et acerrima panurgia: nec vlla quidem praxis multùm potest, sine inuicta, et infinita Audatia: Vnde ad
Tria mea Elementa perpetuò recurrendu[m], peritiam, Assuetudine[m], Zelum: qua[e] dictis, fastisq[ue] potentib[us] operant[u]r miracula.

marginalia.translation: Skillfully and diligently is using the sympathies and antipathies of men and things. That art of miracles, which the mind promises me. The art of men generally corresponds to three sciences: Ethics, Politics, and Eloquence. The art of things likewise corresponds to three sciences: Physics, Mathematics and Engineering. Nothing prevails without daily action and most vigorous craft; nor indeed can any action be much, without invincible and infinite audacity. And so to my three elements that must always return: skill, practice, zeal: through these powerful words and deeds miracles can be achieved.

position.marginalia_text: Reuerâ Talis sis, qualis videri affectas. Solidum gloria[e] fundamentu[m].

marginalia.translation: In fact, be so, like you desire to be seen. The real foundation of glory.
